title: I can't leave this stretch of sidewalk
body:
Hi r/nosleep. Things aren't making sense, and I'm wondering if any of you might be able to help me.

Today was like any other day, until about 10 minutes ago. I got up, got ready, and walked twenty minutes to work. Said hi to Charlotte, the receptionist, and Wesley, the only coworker who I'd consider a friend. I didn't notice until later, but both of them seemed a bit on edge. I worked all morning, and while I didn't think it was odd at the time I didn't see or hear any of my coworkers for the entire morning. The clock finally struck twelve, signalling the start of my lunch break. On my way out, I went to say bye to Wesley, he usually eats at his desk. He stared at his computer and didn't respond. I decided not to bother him and left. Charlotte didn't look up or acknowledge me when I passed her desk.

At the subway across the street, it took several minutes just to get someone to come out of the back and help me. The third time I rang the bell, I was about to leave. The clerk poked her head out of the back and curtly said "We're closed." I was a little offended, but since there was nowhere else nearby to eat and I didn't have my car, I decided I'd just see what snacks we had in the breakroom.

When I arrived at the office, Charlotte, Wesley, and all my other coworkers were nowhere to be found. I thought it was odd, I hadn't seen any of them leave. I found some stale granola bars in a drawer next to the coffee machine, and browsed reddit on my phone while I ate them. When my lunch break ended, I went back to work.

My coworkers didn't return afer lunch. My worry only increased as the clock struck 2, then 3. I just assumed there was some reason they weren't back yet. I sent the boss an email:

Hi Steven,

I've noticed that nobody is at the office. Is there an event I missed the email about?

Sincerely,

John

He responded right away with:

Hi John,

Lately there's been a lot of stuff to do.

Even I have had to stay late.

All of us need to pitch in to get it all done.

Very soon, overtime could become the norm.

Everyone needs to contribute. The

Next couple of days are going to be busy,

On their days off, people might need to come in, but

When it's done, there could be bonuses on top of the overtime pay.

Sincerely,

Steven McGill

I was confused by the cryptic nature of the email. He didn't answer my question, so I assumed there was a reason for it and didn't follow up. For a moment I worried that he might have had a stroke or something, but I didn't know where he was to call 911.

By the time 5:00 came, I was seriously worried, but looking forward to getting home and unwinding. I instinctively said bye to Charlotte's empty desk on my way out, and began to walk home.

There is an abandoned house on my street. I remember that there was a single man who lived there when I moved in, and I remember noticing that he wasn't there anymore a year or two ago. I never saw him much or paid much mind to him or his house, I only noticed his absence when his next-door neighbor told me that she hadn't seen him in some time.

The house was small and run down, siding covered in chipped white paint. One window was broken, revealing a living room filled with dusty furniture. The door always remained firmly shut. I never paid it much mind when I walked past it on my commute.

That brings me to ten minutes ago. I stepped onto the section of sidewalk in front of the abandoned house. I remember getting to the end of the stretch of sidewalk in front of it, only to flinch because of a loud noise just as I stepped across the line between the abandoned house's dying, overgrown lawn and the neatly trimmed green grass of the neighbors. I looked back after flinching to find that I had just stepped onto the section of sidewalk in front of the abandoned house. I thought it must've been Deja Vu or something, and kept walking.

After the third time, I started to worry.

I couldn't leave the sidewalk in front of the house. I'd get to one end only to find myself back at the other end. I even took video of it, but I could never get the transition from one end of the property to the other to look smooth - I'd always jerk the camera or block the lens no matter how careful I was, just like I'd always flinch or zone out for an instant.

That brings me to now. I've still got 25% of my phone's battery left, so I decided I'd stop walking and post here for help. If anyone knows what's happening or how I could escape from this loop, please tell me. I'm getting thirsty, I didn't drink before leaving the office since I thought I'd be home soon, and the sun is hot. Please help.

UPDATE: I walked a couple more circuits. I tried stepping into the road, but whenever I tried I found myself stepping back onto the sidewalk. I took a step onto the abandoned house's property, it seems like I can do that with no issues but since that house seems to be the focus of whatever I'm experiencing I don't want to approach it.

UPDATE 2: I walked along the sidewalk again. I read back over my earlier post. I'm not sure why I talked about a neighbor, or mentioned this house like it was special for being abandoned. All the houses on this street are abandoned. The door to the house is still open, like it was when I got here. Not sure why I said it was always closed. And I don't have any neighbors. Never did. In fact, I think I'm the only person I know. I think I'll go inside, the shade looks so nice and cool. I just hope I don't fall over something, it's far too dark to see anything in there.
author: robots914
